“Do you know, Sonia,” he said, “if I’d killed because I was hungry, I’d be happy now. You must believe that!”

Sonia looked at him, confused. 

“What would it matter to you if I confessed?” he cried. “What do you gain?”

She remained silent, trying to find words.

“I asked you to go with me yesterday,” he continued. “You are all I have left.”

“Go where?” she asked timidly.

“Not to steal or murder,” he smiled bitterly. “I asked you for one thing—not to leave me. You won’t leave me, Sonia?”

She squeezed his hand, her eyes filled with concern.

“Why did I tell her?” he lamented, anguish etched on his face. “You expect an explanation, don’t you?”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov expresses his inner turmoil and desperation for connection with Sonia amidst his guilt and moral conflict.
